and the heel the beginning of the round markes the centre back of the leg heel the construction of this sock includes what is commonly referred to as a strong heel and the main feature of this heel type is an extended leg portion with an integrated gusset that covers the heel and a good portion of the instep work row 1-32 of the heel chart increasing as indicated you should end up with 104 sts at the end of round 32 52 on each needle cut yarn a and change back to the smaller size needles work the remainder of the sock in yarn b only you will now work an extended version of the classic heel turn that is used for many flap + gusset heels this is worked back and forth in row that go across the break between needle 1 and needle 2 you could introduce a third needle if you prefer to work your row without an interruption but keep in mind that the break between the needles is the centre of the sole and will once again be the beginning of the round after the heel turn row1 k2 ssk k1 turn row2
